You'll need to clean up the cppcheck errors by the looks:

 /usr/local/include/gtest/internal/gtest-port.h:2308:0: error: failed to evaluate  #if condition [preprocessorErrorDirective]
 #if __has_include(<any>) && __cplusplus >= 201703L
 ^
 /usr/local/include/sdbusplus/bus/match.hpp:128:22: error: Syntax Error: AST broken, 's' doesn't have a parent. [internalAstError]
    return "sender='"s.append(s).append("',");
                     ^
 /usr/local/include/boost/config/detail/select_stdlib_config.hpp:19:0: error: failed to evaluate #if condition [preprocessorErrorDirective]
 #  if __has_include(<version>)
 ^

DBus is an API to other processes.  What does it mean for an interface to be "Internal" given that definition?  I don't think we should do that.

Further, I think introducing the entire p-d-i code generation process to the building of this repository is a step backwards.  Just add your interface to PDI and drop "Internal" from the name.

Hasn't this been the convention in other repositories where they want a way to trigger between two applications (or a library and application) in the same repository without exposing a public API?

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-debug-collector/blob/ff92ffe29db4099fa44864fc22f40843f4ca1834/xyz/openbmc_project/Dump/Internal/Create.interface.yaml

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/fdd1dc04b56160f03ca774c92c7af92d3dbd24d3/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Logging/Internal/Manager.interface.yaml

A DBus API is by definition public.

It was a convention long ago.  Is it still?  I'm not sure.  I certainly don't advocate for it.

Why can't things other than udev add LEDs?

> A DBus API is by definition public.

It is public in the sense that anyone _could_ make calls to it, but if it is left undocumented and named as "Internal" it seems rather unlikely (and something we should be screening for in a code review).

> Why can't things other than udev add LEDs?

What other entity than udev would indicate that a new sysfs entry exists and should be managed by this application?  That's exactly what udev does.  I can't even think of a way you would know this without udev also knowing it.

This isn't about another application adding an LED.  This is about another adding a sysfs-managed LED, since that is what this repository is about.  If someone comes up with a design where LEDs are not managed via sysfs, they'd need to come up with a design for that.  Maybe at that point it would make sense to define a more globally applicable API?

> It was a convention long ago.  Is it still?  I'm not sure.  I certainly don't advocate for it.

Can you elaborate?  It doesn't seem like we've made any recent suggestions to not do this.

```
$ for f in $(find -name regenerate-meson | grep -v sdbusplus) ; do git -C $(dirname $f) log regenerate-meson | grep Date: | tail -n1 ; done                      
Date:   Wed Jun 24 16:12:44 2020 -0500
Date:   Fri Apr 16 16:30:04 2021 -0500
Date:   Tue Sep 13 11:20:56 2022 -0500
Date:   Thu May 13 18:38:57 2021 -0700
Date:   Wed Sep 8 08:46:22 2021 +0800
```

---

Jayashree is presently trying to keep backwards compatible support for the existing users (which used udev to create N independent processes), while also satisfying the design that was documented at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/55230 .

> I think introducing the entire p-d-i code generation process to the building of this repository is a step backwards.  Just add your interface to PDI and drop "Internal" from the name.

Maybe we need to define a light-weight way to add interfaces to PDI that are intended to be intra-repository?

> It is public in the sense that anyone _could_ make calls to it, but if it is left undocumented and named as "Internal" it seems rather unlikely (and something we should be screening for in a code review).

I don't think we should have undocumented interfaces or be screening for their use.  They should just be documented and allowed to be used, like any other interface.

> What other entity than udev would indicate that a new sysfs entry exists and should be managed by this application?  That's exactly what udev does.  I can't even think of a way you would know this without udev also knowing it.

A developer application?  A testing application?  A manufacturing application?
I'm not sure.  Let me ask it another way - why does udev's use of this API make it special/internal compared to any other OpenBMC application.

> Can you elaborate?

I don't really feel like digging through history to provide examples.  I know I have had conversations about this with others in the past.  I guess I'll just have to hope they are paying attention and speak up if they share my dislike of this practice.

> Jayashree is presently trying to keep backwards compatible support for the existing users 

I appreciate the effort to maintain backwards compatibility.

> Maybe we need to define a light-weight way to add interfaces to PDI that are intended to be intra-repository?

I just don't see the point in the distinction.

> Further, I think introducing the entire p-d-i code generation process to the building of this repository is a step backwards.  Just add your interface to PDI and drop "Internal" from the name.

I disagree. We shouldn't be adding definitions to PDI that we don't want to consider part of the OpenBMC data model. If it's annoying to do per-repo stuff with sdbusplus we should fix that, not shoe-horn everything into PDI because it already makes life easy.

I'm just hoping I'm not too far off with the trade-off between purism and pragmatism there.

> It was a convention long ago.  Is it still?  I'm not sure.  I certainly don't advocate for it.

It's at least an established practice that "Internal" can be a component of an API name for object behaviours that are not for general consumption. If we have a beef with that then we should have a wider discussion about it, not try to change existing practice through commentary in Gerrit buried in some arbitrary patch. Let's get a proposal to docs or something on the mailing list if that's where we want to go and how to deal with existing APIs that fall afoul of the new philosophy.

> Why can't things other than udev add LEDs?

They could, but as Patrick points out that's really the only thing we care about for now, and the likelyhood of something else calling this interface is pretty low.

> A developer application?  A testing application?  A manufacturing application?
I'm not sure.  Let me ask it another way - why does udev's use of this API make it special/internal compared to any other OpenBMC application.

I don't think this is the right question. udev's use of this API isn't special, and the API is also not named in terms of udev. It's not like it's called xyz.openbmc_project.LED.Udev. That said it's not an API that I think deserves representation in the OpenBMC data model either.

Overall I'm fine with the 'Internal' component given that it's existing practice, I'm fine with defining the interface in this repository given that it's also existing practice, and I don't share concerns about things other than udev not being able to call it.

In the interest of moving this forward, I'm happy for it to go in.

Hi Jayashree,

Thanks for continuing to plug away at this. I have a query about the need to commit the generated files, that doesn't quite seem right to me. Is that existing practice?

I've also weighed in on Brad's discussion.

Some good points Andrew.  Overall I think "existing practice" might be getting a more weight than it deserves as rationale (there are other projects in OpenBMC doing this in other ways) and I am slightly worried this will cause some teams in the community to look elsewhere for an LED solution.  However, I think everyone here is very smart and I'm happy to get out of the way and hope I'm wrong 🙂

I feel like I came in a bit hot there, so apologies for how it came across.

> (there are other projects in OpenBMC doing this in other ways)

It was handy that Patrick provided some links to demonstrate the use of Internal - can you provide some to demonstrate these alternatives? I am interested in whether it would change my position above.

> I am slightly worried this will cause some teams in the community to look elsewhere for an LED solution. 

Can you substantiate this worry a bit? Or can you strongly suggest that the people who are concerned comment here? I can't do anything but disregard the concern otherwise, there's nothing actionable I can take away from it. I don't have the bandwidth to invent my own solutions.

> I feel like I came in a bit hot there, so apologies for how it came across.

I didn't notice anything, so no worries.

> to demonstrate these alternatives

Any asio application (these can be mixed with p-d-i fwiw).  Or, for non-asio, something like this:
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-power/blob/master/phosphor-regulators/src/interfaces/manager_interface.cpp

>  I can't do anything but disregard the concern

I understand.  And I think that is the right thing to do..I've already consumed enough of everyone's time here.

Patrick: Do you have concerns with the implementation strategy used by phosphor-power above? Given that it's a private interface, is there any reason to pick the generated-code method over the manual implementation? I see the generated-code method as a mechanism to control the specification of the interface as configuration rather than code, which makes it easier to review. That's nice for interfaces that are part of the core data model, but it's probably less important for interfaces that are private such as this one. Manual implementation means a lot fewer moving parts in the integration.

> Do you have concerns with the implementation strategy used by phosphor-power above? 

It is up to you.  Generally I prefer the generated bindings because they give compile time guarantees of correctness (and I'm working on the client side as well), but for a one-off inside a single repository that is obviously less useful.

Jayashree: I think I prefer the implementation approach demonstrated above in phosphor-power because it's a private interface and that approach requires fewer moving parts. Do you mind reworking this patch along those lines (note I think the rest of the issues are settled, its just the implementation approach)?

Ack
I will work on this patch based on the reference from phosphor-power.

I have submitted the latest patchset based on the reference from phosphor-power to create a new method under xyz.openbmc_project.Led.Sysfs.Internal interface.

Please provide your suggestions on this patchset.
If this is generated we probably shouldn't commit it? Is there some existing practice here?

I referred this yaml/gen file from phosphor-logging reposiory. I can remove this line, if this is not necessary in all the meson.build files.
https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-logging/blob/master/gen/meson.build

It is expected convention to check these in even though they are generated. 

In theory you could do a meson run-command at the top level to create them, but it would increase your [re]build times.  There was a discussion about it when all this gen-scriptage was written and wak was especially opposed to it being done as run-commands, so this is what we settled on.

I prefer a minor change here:

auto ledName = message.unpack<std::string>();
Convention would tend to use 'self' for this.
This whitespace seems unnatural and unnecessary.

Can you early-exit instead of late-exit?  That reduces one level of indentation here.

Do we need to return -EINVAL or is -1 acceptable?
I've commented on the following patch about the direction we should take here.
I've mentioned on the subsequent patch that I think we should squash it into this one, but we also need the actual dbus implementation in there too?
I'd rather you demonstrate what testing was done rather than just asserting that some undefined testing was done.
Hi Jayashree, the series is starting to come together. A couple of comments.
I don't think this is actually exposing anything on DBus?
This patch is to invoke the dbus method for each LED udev event. In the further patches, changes to expose dbus path will be submitted.

Right, but there's no reason to add this code unless it exposes the LED on DBus. 

Broadly, and within a codebase, patches should be created in terms of vertical feature slices. If the patch becomes complex using that approach, the problem should be decomposed into a tree of subproblems that need to be solved, and the patches should be ordered such that the leaf problems are solved first: Specifically, a post-order tree-traversal. Using this technique the general solution emerges from the composition of solutions to the subproblems such that the final patch glues the everything together and exposes the feature atomically.

https://twitter.com/axboe/status/1591538174077317126

The feature in this case is the internal DBus interface for notifying the daemon of a new LED. By the ordering I've just outlined above, the DBus interface should be added in the final patch if there is more than one patch required to do so. As it stands the patch here exposes the internal interface on DBus but invoking its methods has no useful effect. As a maintainer this leads to a poor experience for me because it is harder to reason about external callers and intent and therefore harder to delete the code in the event that the remaining required patches are never merged.

If the code is dead *internal* to the codebase then it's much easier to discover, reason about and delete.

> If the code is dead *internal* to the codebase then it's much easier to discover, reason about and delete.

I missed the final piece: The impact to you is that it's much easier for me to say yes to your patches if they're structured this way :)
Can't you have the map hold the unique_ptr?  I don't see a strong reason to have shared_ptrs.
This shouldn't be a global.  It should be a member of the InternalInterface instance, right?
Why do we have an InternalInterface function implementation in this file?  Don't spread a class implementation over multiple files.

leds.emplace(objPath, make_unique...) ?

I suspect this is where your shared_ptr/unique_ptr trouble is coming from because you shouldn't attempt to get a reference to a default-initialized unique_ptr, which is what you're doing with this code.
Why are we using make_unique and then transfering it to a shared_ptr?  Something fishy is going on here.
Really?  This doesn't seem right.  removeLed calls createLed?
Removing LED will be handled in separate patch.
I would suggest AddLED and RemoveLED to better follow our dbus conventions.
Can this be shared with the client code somehow?

This interface will be created under /xyz/openbmc_project/led dbus path, once the InternalInterface class is invoked from main().

Executable will call the method (AddLED) under the interface "xyz.openbmc_project.Led.Sysfs.Internal" based on udev events.
The daemon functionality you removed in the previous patch should instead be removed in this one, right? That way the change stands on its own.
From the current udev rule I don't think this is a regression as we don't cater to the remove action.

changed it to ```lg2::debug``` since i'm just getting to know these patches.
Let me know if that's ok here.
I'm doing some testing of this series on some of the p10bmc machines. I'll leave some comments when I have results.

I've got DBus-activation going for this series now and it helps a bit, however we need to fix up some name mangling that's occurring, e.g:

```
root@p10bmc:~# busctl tree xyz.openbmc_project.LED.Controller | grep -F '/_'
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/led/physical/_62mc_2dingraham0
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/led/physical/_70ca955x_5fcablecard10_2dcxp_2dbot
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/led/physical/_70ca955x_5fcablecard10_2dcxp_2dtop
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/led/physical/_70cieslot_2dpower
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/led/physical/_72ear_2denc_2dfault0
        |-/xyz/openbmc_project/led/physical/_72ear_2denc_2did0
```

In the process of testing this series I also discovered the existence of "virtual LEDs". They are implemented by passing non-existent paths in sysfs as a commandline argument to phosphor-ledcontroller, which hosts DBus objects whose operations cannot possibly work. This approach, quite frankly, is entirely unjustifiable, however we will need to unwind it to maintain the necessary behaviour.

```
2 15:06:54 andrew@mistburn:~/src/openbmc/openbmc/build/p10bmc  $ git grep sys-class-leds-virtual ../..
../../meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/leds/phosphor-led-manager_%.bbappend:    LINK_FAULT="$D$systemd_system_unitdir/multi-user.target.wants/obmc-led-create-virtual-leds@sys-class-leds-virtual-enc-fault.service"
../../meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/leds/phosphor-led-manager_%.bbappend:    LINK_ID="$D$systemd_system_unitdir/multi-user.target.wants/obmc-led-create-virtual-leds@sys-class-leds-virtual-enc-id.service"
../../meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/leds/phosphor-led-manager_%.bbappend:    LINK_FAULT="$D$systemd_system_unitdir/multi-user.target.wants/obmc-led-create-virtual-leds@sys-class-leds-virtual-enc-fault.service"
../../meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/leds/phosphor-led-manager_%.bbappend:    LINK_ID="$D$systemd_system_unitdir/multi-user.target.wants/obmc-led-create-virtual-leds@sys-class-leds-virtual-enc-id.service"
2 15:26:23 andrew@mistburn:~/src/openbmc/openbmc/build/p10bmc $ git ls-files ../.. | grep obmc-led-create-virtual-leds
../../meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/leds/phosphor-led-manager/obmc-led-create-virtual-leds@.service
2 15:26:40 andrew@mistburn:~/src/openbmc/openbmc/build/p10bmc $ cat ../../meta-ibm/recipes-phosphor/leds/phosphor-led-manager/obmc-led-create-virtual-leds@.service
[Unit]
Description=Create the virtual physical LEDs

[Service]
Restart=always
ExecStart=/usr/libexec/phosphor-led-sysfs/phosphor-ledcontroller -p %f
SyslogIdentifier=obmc-led-create-virtual-leds
```

> however we need to fix up some name mangling that's occurring, e.g:

What is wrong with the mangling?  This looks like the systemd escape stuff.  We've requested everyone move to this manner and if you use the 'object_path' code properly you are getting it for free.

> Description=Create the virtual physical LEDs

Wow.  That stuff is pretty lame.  I wonder why that ever happened considering there are already virtual groups.  I have no idea what a "virtual physical" means.

Is there somewhere where the status of these "virtual physical" LEDs is being actively monitored?  That's kind of against the underlying design in that everything was suppose to monitor the LED groups and not physical LEDs directly.

What were the original LED names to cause the name mangling?

Maybe we can add some replacements for commonly used characters.
In latest revision i added something to replace ```-``` with ```_``` since the former seems to be escaped on dbus.

Closing (no response). Feel free to re-open if there is any direction on how we should handle the name mangling due to object path name restrictions.

https://dbus.freedesktop.org/doc/dbus-specification.html#message-protocol-marshaling-object-path

It doesn't seem like we should blindly ignore this out_of_range.
